Award.AwardTitle: UNS: Transform Municipal Wastewater Treatment Systems into Community Enteric Disease Information Networks

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1507979
Yan

Enteric and diarrheal diseases are a major cause of human illness in the United States and around the world. Major challenges in effectively combating infectious enteric diseases include the lack of real-time information about disease outbreaks and the incapability of quantifying baseline community disease burdens using traditional clinic-based approaches. A novel approach is proposed to transform municipal wastewater treatment systems into community enteric disease information networks, taking advantage of the unparalleled capability of municipal wastewater treatment systems in collecting accurate and real-time enteric disease information from the communities. Preliminary data demonstrated the utility of using molecular tools to quantify and study enteric bacterial pathogens in municipal wastewater, and also showed the possibility of establishing real-time correspondence between pathogen strains in wastewater and in health clinics.

The research goal of this project is to firmly establish the feasibility of using municipal wastewater treatment systems for community disease monitoring. The research hypothesis is that enteric pathogens in municipal wastewater are reliable, quantitative, and real-time indicators of enteric diseases in a community. To test the hypothesis, three specific research objectives, each corresponding to one desirable feature of the hypothesis, will be achieved: (1) determine the decay rates of target bacterial pathogens and reference fecal indicator bacteria in wastewater, (2) determine the quantitative relationship between wastewater pathogen concentration and community enteric disease burden, and, (3) verify real-time detection of community disease outbreaks using Salmonella in municipal wastewater. Overall, this project will investigate the feasibility of a novel approach to address major challenges in community disease monitoring by using existing wastewater infrastructure. This novel approach has the potential to transform the landscape of community disease monitoring, providing game-changing capabilities in understanding the origin, transmission, and evolution of enteric diseases as well as in protecting the public from disease outbreaks. If proven feasible, this will greatly expand the role of wastewater infrastructure in public health protection and provide strong impetus for upgrading and adequately maintaining the wastewater infrastructure. This project will also test and optimize a new high throughput microfluidic qPCR technology for simultaneously quantifying multiple pathogens in municipal wastewater. This will also be the first attempt to determine the quantitative relationships between pathogens in municipal wastewater and corresponding community diseases. Finally, DNA fingerprinting technologies will be used to establish real-time detection of clinically relevant pathogens in municipal wastewater at the strain level. The project proposes a comprehensive plan that will (1) involve Native Hawaiian students in environmental research, and (2) conduct outreach activities to local high school students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Enteric and diarrheal diseases pose major threats to public health, causing approximately 47.8 million illness and 3,037 deaths each year in the United States. Poor sanitation conditions in the developing countries are associated with even more severe enteric disease problems, which was estimated to kill approximately 2 million young children each year in developing countries. For the developed world where foodborne outbreaks are the primary driver of enteric diseases, a major technology challenge is to detect disease outbreaks with limited delay, which would provide precious time for effective implementation of public health control measures. For developing countries where community disease burdens are chronically high, a major challenge is to reliably quantify endemic disease baseline in the absence of an adequate health infrastructure, which is essential for the communities to implement effective prevention and disease reduction measures. Either of the two challenges cannot be effectively addressed by the current enteric disease monitoring mechanisms, which rely almost exclusively on clinical reporting.

This project aims to establish the feasibility of using municipal wastewater treatment systems for community disease surveillance. Microcosm experiments with actual municipal wastewater were conducted to determine the decay kinetics of nucleic acid markers of various human pathogens in the wastewater. The results indicated that the decay of human bacterial pathogen nucleic acid markers in the wastewater collection system only has limited impact on their concentrations at the treatment plants. To determine the quantitative relationship between wastewater pathogen concentration and community enteric disease burden, Salmonella was selected as the model pathogen. The weekly concentration dynamics of Salmonella in Honolulu wastewater was determined over a year, which showed positive correlation with clinical salmonellossi case numbers in the community. To verify real-time detection of community disease outbreaks, a large wastewater Salmonella isolate library was established, DNA-fingerprinted, and compared with clinical Salmonella isolates collected during the same period in the community. Multiple Salmonella strains were detected synchronously in both wastewater and health clinics of the community, supporting the feasibility of using wastewater surveillance for real-time disease outbreak detection. Analysis of the whole genome sequencing (WGS) results of the wastewater Salmonella isolates also identified a Salmonella strain that caused a previous clinically-known outbreak in the community but reemerged in wastewater with high abundance when no clinical outbreak was detected. This suggests that wastewater surveillance could be used to detect clinically-unreported outbreaks and thereby providing new disease surveillance capabilities. The WGS data of wastewater Salmonella also revealed a high community disease burden of a rarely reported and potentially subclinical Salmonella Derby strain in the community, which further expand on the capability of wastewater surveillance beyond the current limits of clinical approaches.
